EVAL_SELECTION.name: Criteria Selection
EVAL_SELECTION.perception_text: Perception problems are associated with human visual processing and interpretation, which, by the nature of AR applications, includes a number of perception factors that are not evaluated in other applications. These problems can be found in implementation problems found in the real environment and problems with devices.
EVAL_SELECTION.ergonomics_text: Ergonomic problems are associated with the behavior of people who use augmented reality. We must bear in mind that the type of interaction that users of augmented reality applications face is very different from the conventional uses of handheld devices and software applications, since the user must hold the device in hand in front of them and the screen confronts them with a combined scene of real and artificial objects.
EVAL_SELECTION.presence_text: Presence is defined as the degree to which a user feels in the real world while experiencing mobile augmented reality. Two main problems have been considered to assess presence: visual realism and sensitive likelihood.
EVAL_SELECTION.availability_text: Availability is defined as a factor that induces action for the user to be able to accurately recognize and operate the meaning of an object with which he interacts in an augmented reality environment. Three main problems have been considered for this attribute: cognitive availability, sensitive availability and physical availability.
EVAL_SELECTION.easy_text: Ease of use is defined as the degree of effectiveness, efficiency, and satisfaction necessary for a user to complete a task in a mobile augmented reality environment. This attribute encompasses five evaluation problems: ease of operation, ease of learning and memory, convenient use, satisfaction and personalization.
EVAL_SELECTION.error_no_select: You must select at least one criteria
EVAL_SELECTION.error_no_id: Something has gone wrong, your evaluation has been dismissed

EXPLANATIONS.name: Explanations
EXPLANATIONS.text1: The questionnaire that we have followed to evaluate the usability of augmented reality applications, CARUS, defines a series of metrics for calculating the final value of usability.
EXPLANATIONS.text2: These metrics define a series of weights for each of the evaluation criteria according to the importance it has at the global level in the usability of an application, in this way we generate the following table of weights:
EXPLANATIONS.text3: Using this table of weights, we have generated the values shown on the information screen of the applications.
EXPLANATIONS.text4: In this way, the value shown for each criterion is the normalization of the value over 100 that results from the questions that make up your questionnaire with their respective weight each. And the total is calculated based on the weight of each of these criteria.
